newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch closing debt market report.
newsitem.headline: Dutch closing debt market report.

text.p: Dutch bonds closed lower after a listless trading session on Wednesday.
Tracking the bund future down in thin volume from the outset of trade, losses deepened in the afternoon when U.S. labour cost data over the first quarter were released.
"I saw some people building up short-positions after the data," one dealer said.
First quarter unit labour costs rose 2.7 percent against an expected 1.0 percent. Productivity was up less than market forecasts, gaining 2.0 percent.
Dealers said a $12 billion auction in ten-year paper in the U.S. due later today had also pressured the Dutch bond prices.
"Looking at the yield curve, it's not very interesting. We have a feeling this auction won't do so well," one trader said.
Trade on the Dutch market was quiet, with many players absent ahead of tommorrow's Ascension Day holiday.
Dealers said there was some activity in the ten-year segment, both in corporate and in government bonds.
The 5.75 percent ten-year benchmark closed nine basis points lower at 100.76/84, yielding 5.64 percent at bid.
Dealers also noted interest in the very short bonds.
"With the very short end now yielding above Germany, you see more people wanting to get into them," one said.
The spread between 1998 Dutch bonds and bunds stood at zero at the end of trade. The Dutch benchmark yielded one basis points above its German counterpart at Tuesday's close.
He said he expected five-year Dutch bonds to yield above German Bunds at the end of this year, foreseeing a return of interest in this segment as well.
"On the very short term, I'm negative, but on the longer term, we believe the market looks good," he said.
"Sentiment is not really bearish, we're just heading for a brief correction," another agreed.
